div1.p: Wood sends his memorandum of the Sullivan manuscript to Kean for corrections. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Leonard Wood to Mark Sullivan, September 7, 1925
div1.opener:
To Mr Mark Sullivan
from Gen Leonard Wood
September 7, 1925.
Dear Mr. Sullivan:
div1.p:
I am forwarding today a memorandum
which I hope will be of some use to you in con-
nection with the historical work which you are
doing. I am sending this memorandum to you
through General Jefferson R. Kean, who was one
of my right-hand men in the yellow fever campaign.
He was also in charge of sanitation during the sec-
ond intervention, 1906-1909. I have asked him,
in case there are any errors in my memorandum, to
correct them and send it back to me. If there are
no serious mirrors, to send it on directly to you.

I am also sending him copy of your
manuscript, with request that he return it to
me as soon as he has read it. It is necessary
to send this to him to check up on the memoran-
dum which I have prepared, to correct any errors
or make any additions if he deems it advisable.
div1.closer:
With kindest regards,
Sincerely yours, Signed Leonard Wood. Mark Sullivan, Esq.,
91 Home Life Building,
Washington, D.C.
